chapter.title: Conceptual Overview
chapter.para: &deng; is a lightweight virtualization solution to run multiple virtual units (containers) simultaneously on a single control host. Containers are isolated with Kernel Control Groups () and .

Full virtualization solutions such as &xen;, &kvm;, or &libvirt; are based on the processor simulating a complete hardware environment and controlling the virtual machines. However, &deng; only provides operating system-level virtualization where the Linux kernel controls isolated containers.

sect1.title: Terminology
sect1.para: Before going into detail about &deng;, let us define some of the terms used:

listitem.para: A container is an instance based on a particular within an execution environment with a set of instructions. Each container can be distinguished by a unique container ID.

Control groups, also called cgroups, are a Linux kernel feature that allows aggregating or partitioning tasks (processes) and all their children into hierarchically organized groups in order to isolate resources.

A text document which contains commands to assemble a &docker; image. With the docker build command, the instructions provided in the Dockerfile are executed by the to create a . The Dockerfile can store modifications you want to apply to the resulting image on top of a base image.

A self-contained piece of software. A &docker; image is a read-only template used to create a virtual machine on the host server. The image is built with a and is made by a series of layers built one over the other. Each layer corresponds to a permanent modification, for example an update of an application. For more details on Docker images, see
the official Docker documentation.
A server-client type application that performs all tasks related to virtual machines. &deng; comprises the following:

formalpara.title: CLI Client:
formalpara.para: Enables you to communicate with the daemon. If the daemon is running on a different machine than the CLI client, the CLI client can communicate by using network sockets or the REST API provided by &deng;.

formalpara.title: Daemon:
formalpara.para: The server side of &deng; manages all &docker; objects (images, containers, network connections used by containers, etc.).

formalpara.title: REST API:
formalpara.para: An API which can be used to directly communicate with the daemon.

listitem.para: An image which is created during the docker build process after each instruction. Each layer is a separate read-only image, except the last which is a read/write layer.
Used by &deng; for its containers to isolate resources reserved for particular containers from other containers or the host system.

In a production environment you typically need a cluster with many containers on each cluster node. The containers must cooperate and you need a framework that enables you to manage the containers automatically. The act of automatic container management is called container orchestration and is typically handled by Kubernetes.
A storage and content distribution for already created images. It typically contains several repositories. There are two types of registry:

formalpara.title: Private Registry:
formalpara.para: Only accessible for particular users or users from a particular private network.

formalpara.title: Public Registry:
formalpara.para: Everyone can download and use images. A typical public registry is Docker Hub.

listitem.para: A storage in a registry that stores a different version of a particular image. You can pull images from a repository or push images to a repository.

An alias for an image. When an image is built, each image layer has a unique identifier. The final image (layer) can be tagged to make it simple to find and reference, instead of having to use the identifier. If an image is not tagged during the build process, its tag defaults to latest.
Isolates applications and operating systems through containers.
Manages allocation of resources in real time, leading to a near-native performance.
Uses cgroups to control network interfaces and resources available inside containers.
Versioning of images.
Allows building new images based on existing ones.
Provides you with container orchestration.
Containers run inside the host system's kernel and cannot use a different kernel.
Only allows Linux guest operating systems.
&deng; is not a full virtualization stack like &xen;, &kvm;, or &libvirt;.
Security depends on the host system. Refer to the official security documentation for more details.

sect1.title: &docker; Images of Applications
sect1.para: &deng; is a technology that can help minimize resources used to run or build applications. There are several types of applications that are suitable to run inside a &docker; container, like daemons, Web pages or applications that expose ports for communication. You can use &deng; to automate building and deployment processes by adding the build process into a &docker; image, then building the image and then running containers based on that image.

sect2.title: Advantages of Running Applications Inside &docker; Containers
sect2.para: Running an application inside a &docker; container has the following advantages:

listitem.para: You can minimize the runtime environment of the application by adding only the required processes and applications to the &docker; image.
Images of an application are portable across machines with different Linux host systems.
You can share an image of an application using a repository.
User-space software running within the container is independent from the user-space software running on the host system. This avoids issues such as library incompatibilities.
You can run several instances of the same application that are completely independent from each other.

sect2.title: Advantages of &deng; to Build Applications
sect2.para: Using &deng; to build applications has the following advantages:

listitem.para: You can prepare a complete build image.
Your build always runs in the same environment.
Developers can test their code in the same environment that is used in production.
You can set up an automated building process.

sect1.title: &deng; Architecture
sect1.para: &deng; uses a client/server architecture. You can use the CLI client to communicate with the daemon. The daemon then performs operations with containers and manages images locally or in the registry. The CLI client can run on the same server as the host daemon or on a different machine.
